body: I live in Japan and have well more than 35 years of experience as a pescatarian here. I have decades of experience in long-drawn out conversations in Japanese in restaurants and in other settings about what specifically vegetariansim and pescatarianism entail. Just this last Saturday I had to explain to four adults (all used to cooking) and 12 children what being a pescatarian entailed (because we were cooking together). I know what I'm talking about.
I’m a native and haven’t had any issues helping traveler friends at restaurants around Japan.  I mean sure, it can be limiting depending on the menu/restaurant but that’s the same anywhere.
I am glad you have not had many troubles. I have had enough to always keep me alert and thorough when talking with food servers.

What time do you arrive ?

That's very, very, very overpacked. You'll be dead tired, quickly. Cut by half, leave a bit of slack, and visit an additional spot if you have time.

Day 1, you won't have enough time to see all that except if you run through each location.

Day 2, you're thinking of a -daytrip- ? that's technically possible, but you'll rush once there and spend half of the day aboard trains, boats or ropeways

Day 3 is almost doable, if you plan properly (Hijiri is not in Akihabara for instance)

Day 4 ... if you don't see any museum in Ueno, maybe...

Day 5 : I am guessing that's a typo and you meant Osaka castle. You're planning to go to Nara (which itself is worth several days, so I am guessing only a couple super touristy spots ?), then Osaka castle, then Dotonbori ? that's too much.

Day 6 : same, quite packed, you'll need to rush through things.

Day 7 : maybe doable if you start early

Day 8 : most of the shops in Jinbocho open at 10, that leaves very much time to visit some shops AND go to a palace tour. Well there are only 2 possible times, 10am and 1:30pm, they last 1h30, so it's going to be very complicated...

TLDR : too much

if you MUST pick one of these, pick #3 (and dont skip the garden at heian jingu, its the only reason to go there)

if there are sakura flowers, #2 may sound great, but #3 still is the better choice AND actually, the philosophers path ends near nanzen-ji, and you can add the keagle incline, which scratches the same itch.

I dont want to imply #1 is inferior to #2 or 3 in impact, but #1 is a lot of bus and walking, two great temples, and then what do you do... where as #3 is a great garden, a great temple, and a huge area with 3,4 or more interesting areas. AND its close to the keagle incline

so the comparison is not entirely fair. anyway. #3 without a doubt
If cherry blossoms are out then Higashiyama and Philosophers Path. Start early to avoid the worst of crowds. Alao Heian-jingu has cherry blossoms
If you do #3, the Philosopher’s path is quite close.

I think option 3 is probably the best, but I am very partial to Nanzen-ji. If you have any spare time you can always take a wander up the Philosopher's Path afterwards. I love that part of Kyoto.

If you choose - for whatever reason - to visit Kinkaku-ji and Ryoan-ji I strongly recommend also visiting Ninna-ji. Ninna-ji does not get much love in this subreddit.
Honestly heian-jingu gardens are awesome regardless, and much easier to get to.
Yeahhhhh, and it's not too far to Nanzen-ji and Keage Incline which are famous cherry blossom spots. At least at Nanzen-ji there's also a lot of space, and many trees so crowds disperse a bit
Yeah Nanzenji is huge. When we were there there was a convention of some sorts and it was still incredibly easy to navigate.
